bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Fulgencio Batista y Zaldivar, January 13, 1953

div1.p: Hench thanks Batista for the dinner party following the Camp Lazear dedication. He stresses that the establishment of the Camp Lazear monument has given pleasure to many Americans. He hopes that the site can become a living memorial by the addition of a public health center.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Fulgencio Batista y Zaldivar, January 13, 1953
div1.opener:
January 13, 1953
The Honorable Senor President of the Republic of Cuba
Major General Fulgencia Batista
The Palace
Habana, Cuba
My dear President Batista:
div1.p:
On my return from Habana and the dedication of Camp Lazear I was at once
caught up in the activities of the Christmas - New Year holidays with our
home once again filled with all of our children back from school.

May I express to you, President Batista, my somewhat belated but very
sincere thanks for your courtesy in inviting me to join you and Senora
Batista on the happy occasion of your dinner for Miss Louise Wood at
The Palace on the night of December 6. It was a delightful occasion
which your five guests from the United States will always remember with
pleasure. I have just received from Doctor Capote three more photo-
graphs of the dinner party which I am delighted to have.

I regret very much that Mrs. Hench, who has visited Habana so often with
me and who joins me in cherishing our close friendship with many Cubans,
was unable to go with me on this felicitous occasion when you and your
countrymen, by the act of memorializing Campamento Lazear on the Finca
San Jose, Quemados, paid such a distinguished and lasting tribute to my
countrymen, Drs. Walter Reed, Jesse Lazear, James Carroll and their as-
sociates, uniting their names in honored memory with that of your pre-
eminent and well-loved Carlos Finlay.

These great men, each making his own contribution to a common cause,
together did so much, not only for the people of their own two countries,
yours and mine, but for all mankind.

Your establishment of Campamento Lazear as a National Monument has given
great satisfaction and pleasure to Americans of many classes, especially
to the American medical profession and to the Medical Department of the
United States Army. Major General George Armstrong, the Surgeon General,
and his associate, Major General Streit, and officers of the American
Medical Association have written me expressing their great interest in
the ceremony of dedication. I am sending to them and to the sons and
daughters of Drs. Reed, Lazear and Carroll a full report concerning this
gracious gesture and this fine example of Cuban friendship for us. Also
I will shortly describe the dedication of the “Parque Monumento Nacional
Campamento Lazear” to my colleagues of the staff of the Mayo Clinic at
The Honorable Senor President of the Republic of Cuba
Page 2
January 13, 1953
one of our general staff meetings. Furthermore it will be my privilege
to call this new medical shrine to the attention of various United States
associations related to medicine, public health and sanitation. Many of
them will, I am sure, be anxious to visit it during their conventions in
Habana.

Ministro Saladrigas and others, so I understand, have expressed the hope
that the Memorial Park, fine as it is, will be only the beginning of a
larger, living memorial for the people of Habana and Quemados which may
take the form of a public health unit or other useful structure. Erected
on the very site of old Campamento Lazear where the earnest hopes of
Cuban and American scientists for the conquest of yellow fever were
realized as a result of an unequaled cooperative adventure, such a living
memorial would certainly epitomize magnificently the wonderful tradition
of Cuban-American friendship and cooperation, and of the inter-nationality
of scientific endeavor.

I would be more than delighted to cooperate in the raising of American
funds to help support such a Cuban-American memorial.

President Batista, after your dinner party I was so glad to have you tell
me of your great admiration for Abraham Lincoln and of your library of
books about him. Permit me to send you what I am told is the latest
book on his life, a book which is receiving excellent reviews and which
appears to be outstanding in some ways. I do hope that this will be
now to you and that you will enjoy it.

Accept it as a small token of my very real friendship for you and your
countrymen. Please also convey to Senora Batista my kind regards and
sincere thanks.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
